review.title: A Sentence Simplification System for Improving Relation Extraction
review.abstract: In this demo paper, we present a text simplification approach that is directed at improving the performance of state-of-the-art Open Relation Extraction (RE) systems. As syntactically complex sentences often pose a challenge for current Open RE approaches, we have developed a simplification framework that performs a pre-processing step by taking a single sentence as input and using a set of syntactic-based transformation rules to create a textual input that is easier to process for subsequently applied Open RE systems.

metadata.title: A Sentence Simplification System for Improving Relation Extraction

sections.text: In this demo, we present a text simplification approach aimed at improving the performance of modern Open Relation Extraction (RE) systems. Since syntactically complex sentences are often a challenge to current Open RE approaches, we have developed a simplification framework that performs a pre-processing step by using a single sentence as input and using a set of syntactical transformation rules to generate text input that is easier to process for subsequent Open RE systems.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Relation Extraction (RE) is the task of recognizing the assertion of relationships between two or more entities in NL text. Traditional RE systems have focused on identifying and extracting relationships of interest by taking the target relationships as input, along with handmade extraction patterns or patterns learned from hand-labeled training examples. As a result, moving to a new domain requires first specifying the target relationships and then manually creating new extraction rules or commenting new training examples by hand (Banko and Etzioni, 2008). Since these manual workscales are linear with the number of target relationships, this supervised approach does not require scaling to large, heterogeneous companies, which are likely to include a variety of unexpected relationships (Schmidek and Barbosa, 2014). To address this problem, Banko and Etzioni (2008) are developing a new extraction parameter called "Open Relationship" that facilitates the discovery of fear.

sections.heading: 2 System Description
sections.text: In fact, the idea of our text simplification framework is to replace a complex input sentence by splitting coherent clauses into individual sentences and removing specific syntactical sub-structures, namely those that contain little information. Unlike other approaches to extractive sentence compression, we have not deleted these sentences, which would result in a loss of background information, but rather aim to preserve the full informative content of the original sentence. Thus, on the basis of syntax-driven heuristics, components that typically only provide secondary context sentences are adopted by means of paraphrasing operations. Defining the rules of simplification By analyzing the structure of hundreds of examples from English Wikipedia, we have determined election judgments that do not typically provide stand-alone context sentences.

sections.heading: 4 Usage
sections.text: The Text Simplification Framework is available to the public both as a library and as a command-line tool, the workflow of which is illustrated in Figure 1. It takes NL text as input either in the form of a single sentence or a file with line-separated sentences. As described above, each input sentence is first converted into a structurally simplified version, consisting of 1 to n core sentences and 0 to m associated context sentences. In a second step, the relationships contained in the input are extracted by applying the Open IE System3 to the simplified sentences. Finally, the results thus generated are written to the console or a specific output file in JSON format. As an example, the result that our simplification system generates when applied to a complete Wikipedia article.4

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have described a syntax-based framework for simplifying texts that simplifies the linguistic structure of input sentences, with the aim of improving the coverage of modern Open-RE systems. Experimental analysis has shown that simplifying text before processing improves the outcome of current Open-RE approaches, resulting in less loss of information and greater accuracy of extracted relationships.

However, particularly in long and syntactically complex sentences, relevant relations often span several clauses or are presented in a non-canonical form (Angeli et al., 2015), thus posing a challenge for current Open RE approaches which are prone to make incorrect extractions while missing others - when operating on sentences with an intricate structure.

Referring to previous attempts at syntax-based sentence compression (Dunlavy et al., 2003; Zajic et al., 2007; Perera and Kosseim, 2013), the idea of our text simplification framework is to syntactically simplify a complex input sentence by splitting conjoined clauses into separate sentences and by eliminating specific syntactic sub-structures, namely those containing only minor information.
